p:
The cumulative urine samples collected over five hours were analyzed for the electrolytes content (Na +, K +, and Cl
â€“ ) ( Table 3). All the three doses of aqueous extract tended to increase Na + excretion by at least 201% ( p<0.001) compared to NC group. Likewise, the methanolic extract produced significant Na + excretion with all doses by 159.8%, ( p<0.01), 294.6% and 339.2% ( p<0.001) from low to high dose, respectively. The standard drug, however, increased Na + level significantly (542.5%, p<0.001) compared to NC.
